audio_description: As-salaam-alaikum, today I’m sharing with you the recipe to make Awadhi Biryani. You’ve probably made many types of biryani before—spicy, full of masalas—but Awadhi Biryani is completely different.

actions: Pouring kewra water into the bowl
Stirring the mixture in the pot
Adding turmeric powder to the hot oil

Adding shredded cheese to the pot
Pouring marinated chicken pieces into the pot with cheese
Pouring orange sauce over the marinated chicken and cheese
Mixing rice and vegetables with meat using a spoon
Served rice and meat in a bowl

audio_description: To make this biryani, first take 5 cups (1 kg) of long-grain, high-quality basmati rice. Wash the rice well 3–4 times and then soak it for half an hour.

Adding kewra water to the bowl

audio_description: Awadhi Biryani is all about aroma. It’s built on fragrance, not heavy spices. That’s why I’m adding 2 tablespoons of kewra water. Also add 3 tablespoons of ginger paste.

audio_description: As you can see, very few spices are used here—that’s the specialty. Now add some whole spices: 7–8 small green cardamoms, 1 large black cardamom, 1/4 piece of nutmeg, 2 cloves.

audio_description: Now set this marinade aside for 15–20 minutes. Meanwhile, boil water for the rice—about 4 to 5 liters. Add 2-inch cinnamon sticks, 4–5 small cardamoms, and 7–8 cloves.

audio_description: Let the biryani cook on dum for about 25 minutes on low heat. Don’t open the lid in between. Keep it fully covered so the biryani steams perfectly. Your Awadhi biryani is now ready with beautiful aroma.

audio_description: How did your biryani turn out? Mine turned out great—everyone loved it, Mashallah. You’ve probably made many spicy biryanis—try this fragrant Awadhi biryani once; you’ll love it.
I hope you liked this recipe. Please try it and give me your feedback. Let me know how your Lucknow-style Awadhi biryani turned out.
